====2 February====

====2 February â Battle of the Camel====
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|240px|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|240px|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
During the night of 1–2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria where shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 2 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many protesters from the previous day had remained in Tahrir Square overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
During the night of 1–2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria where shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 2 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many protesters from the previous day had remained in Tahrir Square overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
Line 220: Line 220:
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Egypt Unrest |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> By midday, the army was asking protesters to go home in order to stabilise the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: Only the Egyptian Army Has Power To Restore Stability|work=[[National Post]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> State-television then announced: "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Egypt Unrest |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> By midday, the army was asking protesters to go home in order to stabilise the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: Only the Egyptian Army Has Power To Restore Stability|work=[[National Post]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> State-television then announced: "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/>
â
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters – The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs came riding on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> including Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref> Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
+
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters – The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs came riding on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> including Tahrir Square<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref> in what is later known as the ('''Battle of the Camel''' or '''Battle of Jamal'''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12369422|title=Egyptian media: State misinformation amid the protests?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=04 February 2011|accessdate=09 February 2011}}</ref>) Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the Egyptian Museum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> ''CNN'' interviewed a few anaylsts who suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" has been tried-and-tested at numerous times in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting it could be the same this time despite Interior Ministry denials.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the Egyptian Museum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> ''CNN'' interviewed a few anaylsts who suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" has been tried-and-tested at numerous times in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting it could be the same this time despite Interior Ministry denials.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
